Hey Tim, We know Elon Musk/SpaceX is working on a way to re-use the second stage of the Falcon 9, I was surprised to see ULA getting in on the act as well. investors.com ran a story about SpaceX’s Falcon 9 block 5, in the story I read something very interesting. “Rival United Launch Alliance, a Boeing- Lockheed Martin (LMT) joint venture, is looking at upper stage reusability with the company's Advanced Cryogenic Evolved Stage. But ULA sees that spacecraft being left in orbit for months or years and refuelled.” https://www.investors.com/news/spacex-elon-musk-predictions-reusable-falcon9-lower-costs/ Why would anyone leave the thing in space I’m not sure? The idea of a refuelling station for the second stage is interesting! can someone tell me if this is a viable idea? Trolls and flat earthers will be ignored.:)

comment_text: I'd like to patent a way for spacex to maintain a sat like on the ship during reentry.  step 1. remove sat dish from barge. step 2. send signal over ethernet down a long stretch of cable to a dingy. step 3. place dish on dingy and click "send".  dingy is less likely to get shaken and you won't lose signal. :)

Today I noticed something different about the launch pad. They completely removed the Shuttle payload adapter. It looks so much cleaner without that big bunch of useless girders right there in the way of everything.

Here is a SpaceX question I'd love you to answer some time:

How many (and which) pre-bock 5 boosters might I one day be able to go see in a museum?

SpaceX have landed lots of pre-block 5 boosters, but they've adopted a policy that pre-5 can only be launched twice, and they then don't recover them after the second launch, so lots of potential museum pieces are falling into the ocean. However, there are some exceptions: the first booster they ever landed is on display at SpaceX HQ. The two side boosters of the Falcon Heavy launch were both pre-flown, and have been recovered, so can't fly again (unless SpaceX chane their mind). I think the first time they flew a pre-flown booster they recovered it, as the throw-away-on-second-flight policy was not then in place.

Am I right on all of these? Are there any other boosters that have been recovered after a second flight? Have SpaceX ever indicated what might happen to these?

Yesterday in the previous attempt they said (22:57 of scrubbed video) that they previously held the chamber pressure constant and the thrust was dependent on both the internal chamber pressure and the external atmospheric pressure. As such, the thrust would increase as the rocket ascended. In this launch they are attempting to have a constant thrust and in order to achieve this they are decreasing the internal chamber pressure. Not sure if the reason for this is to increase the Specific Impulse or not, but that is a reasonable guess.
